question.p: In a certain corporation, there are 300 male employees and 100 female employees. It is known that 25% of the male employees have advanced degrees and 40% of the females have advanced degrees. One employee is chosen at random.

ol.li:
What is the chance that the employee has an advanced degree and is female?
40/400

What is the chance that the employee has an advanced degree or is female?
175/400

If it is known that the employee selected is female, what is the chance that the employee has an advanced degree?
40/100

If it is known that the employee selected has an advanced degree, what is the chance that the employee is female?
40/115

question.p: A coin will be tossed 10 times.

ol.li:
Without doing any calculations, which chance is greater: that there will be exactly 6 heads total, or that there will be exactly 2 heads among the first 5 tosses and exactly 4 heads among the last 5?
6 heads total 2 heads among first 5 tosses, 4 heads among last 5 The chances are the same.

What is the chance that there will be exactly 6 heads total?
210*(1/2)^10

What is the chance that there will be exactly 2 heads among the first 5 tosses and exactly 4 heads among the last 5?
10*5*(1/2)^10

question.p: At the first full moon of fall quarter, a group of three seniors walk to the Main Quad to kiss freshmen. Each senior asks 5 freshmen for permission to kiss. There is a 60% chance a freshman wants to be kissed, and a 40% chance the freshman refuses. Assume independence thoughout.

ol.li:
First consider only one of the three seniors. What are the chances that this senior will kiss at least one freshman?
1-(.4)^5 .98976

What are the chances that at least one in the group of three seniors has to go home without having kissed anybody?
1-(.98976)^3

question.p: You are writing an 8 page paper. There is a 40% chance you make no errors on a page, a 30% chance you make 1 error, a 20% chance you make 2 errors, and a 10% chance you make 3 or more errors. Assume the numbers of errors on pages are independent.

ol.li:
What is the chance that you make errors on fewer than 2 pages?
8*(.6)^1*(.4)^7 + (.4)^8

What is the chance you make no more than 1 error on at least 7 of the pages?
8*(.7)^7*(.3)^1 + (.7)^8

hw.question:
The ELISA test screens donated blood for the presence of the AIDS virus. The test works by detecting antibodies, substances that the body produces when the virus is present, but it makes some mistakes. ELISA was designed so that when a given blood sample is in fact contaminated with AIDS, the test gives a positive result (that is, ELISA reports that in its opinion this blood sample has AIDS in it) 99% of the time, whereas when the blood being tested is not contaminated with the virus ELISA will announce a negative result 94% of the time. The prevalence of AIDS in the population of people who donate blood is thought to be about 1%. Suppose someone comes in, donates blood, and the ELISA test comes out positive. What is the chance that they actually have AIDS?
You can round your answer to this problem. We are looking for a percentage.
[14, 14.5] 14.3 %

question.p: A multiple choice exam has 10 questions. Each question has 4 possible answers, of which one is correct. A student knows the answers to 3 of the questions and answers them correctly. The student guesses the answers to the remaining 7 questions at random.

ol.li:
What is the chance the student answers exactly 7 of the 10 questions correctly?
35*(1/4)^4*(3/4)^3 [.057,.06]

Given that an answer is correct, what is the chance the student was merely guessing the answer?
(.7*.25)/(.7*.25+.3*1) [.36,.37]
